dialogs.original: I would not by my will have troubled you,But, since you make your pleasure of your pains,I will no further chide you.
dialogs.translated: I didn't want to trouble you, but you seem to take pleasure in enduring suffering, so I won't scold you about it anymore.

dialogs.original: I could not stay behind you. My desire,    More sharp than filèd steel, did spur me forth.    And not all love to see you, though so much    As might have drawn one to a longer voyage,    But jealousy what might befall your travel,    Being skilless in these parts, which to a stranger,    Unguided and unfriended, often prove    Rough and unhospitable.   My willing love,    The rather by these arguments of fear,    Set forth in your pursuit.
dialogs.translated: I couldn't stay behind. My desire to go was sharper than a knife, and it spurred me onward. It wasn't just love for you, though that much might have inspired a man to go on an even longer voyage. I was also worried about what might happen to you in your travels, since you don't know this area, and it can be rough and inhospitable to a stranger without a guide or friend. My willing love for you, combined with these fears for your safety, drove me to follow you.

dialogs.original: My kind Antonio,    I can no other answer make but thanks,    And thanks, and ever thanks.   And oft good turns    Are shuffled off with such uncurrent pay.    But were my worth as is my conscience, firm,    You should find better dealing.   Whats to do?    Shall we go see the relics of this town?
dialogs.translated: My kind Antonio, the only answer I can give you is thanks, and thanks, and infinite thanks. Often such good deeds are only rewarded with cheap words, but if I had any wealth I would strengthen my gratitude with money. Now what should we do? Should we go see the monuments of this town?

dialogs.original: Tomorrow, sir. Best first go see your lodging.
dialogs.translated: We'll do that tomorrow, sir. First we should find a place for you to stay.

dialogs.original: I am not weary, and tis long to night:    I pray you, let us satisfy our eyes    With the memorials and the things of fame    That do renown this city.
dialogs.translated: I'm not weary, and night is a long way away. Please, let's go satisfy our eyes with the sight of the memorials and statues that make this city famous.

dialogs.original: Would youd pardon me;    I do not without danger walk these streets:    Once in a sea-fight 'gainst the Count his galleys    I did some service, of such note indeed,    That were I ta'en here it would scarce be answered.
dialogs.translated: I hope you'll pardon me: I can't walk these streets without being in danger. Once in a battle at sea I served on the side fighting against Duke Orsino's ships, and I distinguished myself enough that I might be recognized. If I were arrested here, they'd make me answer for my deeds.

dialogs.original: Belike you slew great number of his people?
dialogs.translated: Then you must have killed many of his men?

dialogs.original: The offence is not of such a bloody nature;    Albeit the quality of the time and quarrel    Might well have given us bloody argument.    It might have since been answered in repaying    What we took from them, which, for traffics sake,    Most of our city did.   Only myself stood out;    For which, if I be lapsèd in this place,    I shall pay dear.
dialogs.translated: My deeds weren't so bloody as that, though we had just cause to shed some blood over that quarrel. We could have since resolved the matter by paying reparations for the damage we did to them in battle, for the sake of maintaining our trade relations. Most of our city did. I was the only one who refused to pay anything. That's why I'll pay dearly if I should be cap here.

dialogs.original: Do not then walk too open.
dialogs.translated: Then don't walk around too conspicuously.

dialogs.original: It doth not fit me. Hold, sir, heres my purse.    [giving him money]    In the south suburbs, at the Elephant,    Is best to lodge.   I will bespeak our diet,    Whiles you beguile the time and feed your knowledge    With viewing of the town. There shall you have me.
dialogs.translated: It's not a good idea for me, certainly. Wait, sir, here's my purse. [Giving SEBASTIAN some money] The best place to stay is an inn called the Elephant. It's in the suburbs to the south. I'll order our meals while you spend your time pleasantly and educate yourself by exploring the town. You can find me back at the Elephant.
Why should I take your purse, though?

dialogs.original: Haply your eye shall light upon some toy    You have desire to purchase,   and your store,    I think, is not for idle markets, sir.
dialogs.translated: Just if some trinket should catch your eye and you want to buy itI have the feeling that your store of money isn't large enough for useless purchases.

dialogs.original: Ill be your purse-bearer and leave youFor an hour.
dialogs.translated: I'll carry your purse then, and leave you for an hour.
And meet me at the Elephant.
